title: Daily Rate to Salary Calculator
description: Convert your daily consulting or contract rate into an equivalent annual salary.
methodSummary: Annual Salary = Daily Rate × Days per Week × Weeks Worked
assumptions: Assumes a flat consulting daily rate without half-day fractional billing.
Assumes 52 weeks in a calendar year.
insights: Never multiply your daily rate by 260 (52 weeks × 5 days) without subtracting vacations, sick days, and non-billable bench time. 220 or 230 days is a safer maximum.
A £400 daily rate might seem incredibly high, but once you subtract self-employment taxes, missing pension contributions, and unpaid holidays, it roughly equates to a £65k salary, not £100k+.

faqs.q: How many working days are there in a standard year?
faqs.a: There are generally 260 to 262 working days (Monday-Friday) in a year, depending on leap years.

faqs.q: Should I charge a higher daily rate than my current salary division?
faqs.a: Yes. Daily rate contractors should typically charge a 30-50% premium over their salaried daily equivalent to absorb the risk of downtime and lack of benefits.

faqs.q: How do I account for public holidays?
faqs.a: Subtract the public holidays from your total working weeks. Instead of 52 weeks, calculate using 46 or 47 weeks.

faqs.q: Why is daily rate common in IT and Consulting?
faqs.a: It simplifies billing for clients. They don't have to track your hourly movements, and you are paid for output per day rather than punching a clock.

faqs.q: Does this tool work if my weekly days vary?
faqs.a: Use an average. If you work 3 days one week and 5 the next, input 4 days per week.

faqs.q: Can I use this to compare a contract offer to an employment offer?
faqs.a: Yes, but remember to discount the calculated annual salary by around 20-30% to find the true 'salaried' equivalent value.
